Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Wearable Direct Read Monitors for Personal Exposure Assessment to Toxic Gases
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will lead to the development of a new class of liquid crystal (LC)-based direct-read monitors (DRMs) for detection of nitrogen dioxide (NO2) present in air at construction sites. The approach to development of DRMs that is described in this proposal is based on the innovative use of LC materials to detect and report molecular interactions on chemically functionalized surfaces. Results obtained under Phase I research will demonstrate that sensors comprised of a chemically functionalized surface supporting a thin film of nematic LC can detect NO2 in air at levels required to meet worker safety standards established by regulatory agencies.

The broader impact of this research is the reduction of hazardous chemicals exposure risk to 139 million US citizens at their work place. This Phase I SBIR proposal is focused on protecting the health of 9 million workers in the US construction industry, workers who have been documented to be at increased risk of chronic exposure to NO2 in air due to regular use of various tools, equipments, and vehicles powered by diesel engines. This DRM platform, while initially focused on detection of NO2 within construction zones, has the potential to be broadly useful for detection of a range of hazardous gases encountered in occupational settings in the US.

Intellectual Merit:

One hundred thirty nine million US citizens work in environments that subject them to risks of occupational exposure to hazardous chemicals. Hazardous chemical exposure in the US workplace has been responsible for an estimated 860,000 occupational illnesses and 60,000 deaths; with an annual estimated cost of $171 billion. This SBIR Phase I project targeted the development of an entirely new class of liquid crystal (LC)-based direct-read monitors (DRMs) for detection of hazardous gases of relevance to occupational health, with a specific focus on sensors designed to detect nitrogen dioxide (NO2) present in air at construction sites. These DRMs are integrated systems composed of a sensing element, sensor readout electronics with a display, audible alarm and memory capable of storing data points for specified sampling periods. The approach to development of DRMs was based on the innovative use of LC materials to detect and report molecular interactions on chemically functionalized surfaces. The goal of this project was to demonstrate that sensors comprised of a chemically functionalized surface supporting a thin film of nematic LC can detect NO2 in air at levels required to meet worker safety standards [0.1-10 parts per million (ppm)]. Key research activities included identification of the optimal surface chemistry and LC composition for selective detection of NO2 and characterization of key attributes of the sensors under conditions relevant to the workplace environment. Results from this Phase I research demonstrated feasibility of a sensor that is specific for NO2 and is resistant to interference from other gases that are likely to be present in air at construction sites. Although significant advancement has been made toward achieving the goal of reversible detection of 0.1-10 ppm NO2 under a minute, some issues related to the sensitivity, the speed and reproducibility in sensor recovery still remain unresolved. We have identified a few potential approaches to resolve these outstanding issues that will enable us to continue development of these sensors. In subsequent research, we will integrate the sensor element with other commercially available components (LEDs, photodetectors, electronics) to develop a cost effective wearable DRM and validate its performance in collaboration with industry leaders in occupational safety.   

 

Broader Impact:

This project was focused on protecting the health of 9 million workers in the US construction industry, workers who are at increased risk of chronic exposure to NO2 in air due to regular use of various tools, equipment (e.g., welding), and vehicles powered by diesel engines (recent changes in diesel engine technology are leading to increase in NO2 emissions). While federal regulation requires that NO2 concentrations in the work place be maintained below specified levels, existing sensing technologies (electrochemical cells, solid-state semiconductors and photometric analyzers) for measurement of NO2 exposure are not optimal for monitoring of personal exposure of construction workers because they are cumbersome, prohibitively expensive, require on-site calibrations, and/or are prone to yielding false positive results.
